ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course gave me a foundational understanding in many statistics concepts. JDRS does a very good job of making the content accessible to students who have very little prior knowledge in the subject area.
learned basic stats with no prior knowledge
Have a very good understanding of basic statistics.
I learned a lot about statistics. My favorite things I have learned are multiple regression, ANOVA, and how to use mini tab.
Basic understanding of stats/statistical methods

I learned critical skills of statistics and especially how to discern/analyze data. I also learned the flaws in data and not to trust all the data presented in the media or news, unless you're able to understand how the data was retrieved and how it was distributed. This class was a great introduction to many key and foundational principles of statistics.
More advances statistical understanding.
This was a solid introduction to statistics and its practical applications.

Having never taking a statistics class before, I gained knowledge and a wide range of statistical tools to apply in many scenarios (including regression, ANOVA, box plots, probability, etc.). I appreciated how interdisciplinary the course was and how applicable Minitab was.
A good introduction to statistics, especially for non-stem majors
Basic understanding of statistics and evaluating models
I learned the fundamentals of statistics and how to use it for political science.
I now have an excellent understanding of statistics.
I developed a toolkit of basic statistic skills that went beyond my previous knowledge from high school and into more complex data analysis.
Basic statistical analysis
i developed my data analysis skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Having both in person and recorded lectures made the course very accessible and easy to participate in. PSets were easily structured that evaluated students understanding of concepts in class and less of strict busy work. JDRS is also a pleasure too watch teach and makes classes very enjoyable.
Asynchrony format -- at your own pace. never had to go to class in-person. more zoom office hours would be helpful

Help is very accessible and you can do the modules whenever it is convenient for you. The only weakness was that for the first half of semester I felt like I didn't understand the bigger picture of what we were learning.

The fact that you have a choice of whether to attend in-person lecture or watch pre-recorded videos is INCREDIBLE, and as someone who very much struggles with statistics as a concept, this was so, so helpful.

Strengths: the fact you can go to in person lecture, watch the lecture, or watch ore-recorded lectures. Making the class accessible for everyone. The Professor is a very engaging man, 
Weakness: the class moves extremely fast.

Strengths: well-organized and structured for successful student learning, assignments are manageable, easy to engage in the way most effective for personal learning
Improvements: JDRS could slow down a bit in his lecturing - sometimes he flies past things and it's hard to understand him

This course being live in-person, asynchronous, and live virtually, was incredibly helpful and made class accessible to students at all times. For me personally, I appreciated being able to hike up science hill to attend class in-person for the first couple of weeks, but as my schedule become more stringent and the weather got colder, I liked being able to attend class virtually. This plus the floods of office hours throughout the semester made learning incredibly accessible and it left it up to me as a student to decide how engaged I wanted to be. I think sometimes class would go very fast and we didn't have much time to sit with some of the terms and concepts learned in class, this I think could've made learning a little more difficult.

A big strength of this course is its flexibility. The course can be taken at any time because there are pre-recorded modules. All of the exams are take-home and open-note. This is a wonderful and amazingly flexible course. Another great thing is that there are office hours for this class literally every day bc there are a million TAs. 

I have no notes. This class has no weaknesses.

Prof. JDRS has structured the course to offer it completely asynchronously if that's what you prefer.  All of the lectures are pre-recorded and also offered in person which made it really easy to learn and review the course material.  The notes that JDRS provides are extremely comprehensive and helpful.  I felt that the course had a lot of support available, but office hours with ULAs were pretty unreliable, especially toward the end of the semester.  There were several times when I tried to attend Zoom office hours, with other students also in the Zoom room, but the ULA was not there.
A strength was that the pre-recorded lectures allowed students to move along at their own pace. It would have been nice if the p-sets weren't as long but were instead more frequent.
The TFs need to consistently show up to their hours and a lot of them did Not know what they were doing and could not help.
A strength is the ability to take this class synchronously or asynchronously, depending on personal preference

Strengths: LOVED the different ways to take the course and the amount of office hours opportunities 
Weaknesses: none!
strengths: excellent course. workload super manageable and TAs very helpful.
The notes were organized and the asynchronous structure of the class was favorable, but TAs were consistently unavailable and made many grading mistakes throughout the year.
Its asynchronous nature makes it really easy to not be engaged. More incentive to come to in-person lecture would be useful
this course covered the material well

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. This is a very good class to get your QR distributional requirement that is also applicable to other parts of life down the line. JDRS is a pleasure and any chance to learn with him you have you should take.
yes. doable QR credit, asynchronous, learned stats without stressing much of my grade
Yes -- it is very good to have an understanding of statistics.

I would recommend this course to people that have already taken a course similar to AP statistics. If you dont already have previously statistics knowledge it will be a very difficult class as we breeze through topics.
Yes, a good course for anyone who needs basic stats or who needs a QR credit

I definitely would recommend this course to other students. I think it's great for students interested in data science that aren't well versed in it yet. After taking this course students will have a solid grasp of statistics and terms that matter when it comes to measuring data across the world.
I absolutely would recommend and HAVE recommended this course to many other students. It's a wonderfully flexible course that made learning statistics easy.

Yes - especially with JDRS.  There is a lot of material, but all of the supports are available to help you learn it.  Learning intro stats has been really helpful in understanding methods in scientific/academic papers that I read in my other classes.
Yes. Don't be afraid to tackle this course in R instead of Minitab, it is very doable.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if they have never taken a stats course and are looking for a very useful class that applies to almost any major or job.

This is a good introduction to stats, but I can see how this course would be hard/a lot of material to learn for someone who hasnt taken AP Stats. Its interesting and relative to real world events. Would definitely recommend for social sciences majors in need of a QR.
Absolutely, it is a good introduction for the field and helpful for anyone in the humanities.
Yes, especially for a math credit for non stem majors
Yes! It was a great introduction to statistics and extremely applicable to the real world.
yes!
The class material made sense generally but expect to learn the material almost entirely on yourself as the TAs are very unavailable. Also, many grading mistakes are made in this class.
Yes.
It is a good basic introduction if you are not going to take any other stats classes!
Yes, it was a good QR credit and provided a statistical analysis base.
